object-03.text:
Let us familiarize ourselves with the features that we need to see in a wood species so we can identify it through this learning object entitled:

		WHEN YOU SEE IT, NAME IT! Structural Features of Wood: Things to look for to identify a wood species

object-04.text: WHEN YOU SEE IT, NAME IT! Structural Features of Wood: Things to look for to identify a wood species

object-06.text: At the end of this learning object, the viewer should be able to:

object-07.text:
At the end of this learning object, the viewer should be able to:

		a. describe the different structural features that are present in wood;

object-10.text: At the end of this learning object, the viewer should be able to:

object-11.text:
At the end of this learning object, the viewer should be able to:

a. describe the different structural features that are present in wood;

object-16.text: I have finally arrived in the wood institute.

object-17.text: Wow! The wood collection here is so huge. There are plenty of wood species that we have discussed in class. I hope to learn all of these during my stay here as intern.

object-18.text: Hmmm... I am wondering where are the staff in this wood library?

object-20.text: Hi, I am Forester Pips, one of the staff in this wood library. How may I help you?

object-21.text: Hello, I am Sue, a BS Forestry Student from UP Los Banos. I applied here as a student intern who wish to learn and become familiar on these wood samples.

object-22.text: Ow great! So you are Ms. Sue, my supervisor, For. Van, told about your arrival today. By the way, she requested me to assist you for the entire period of your stay here.

object-23.text: Excellent! Thank you, For. Pips. Nice to meet you :)

object-25.text: Sue, as our intern in this Institute, one of your tasks is to do inventory of wood samples. There are approximately 150 species across 30 families. Your professor in UPLB also told us to teach you identify various wood samples by simply looking at the structural features.

object-26.text: Yes, I would love to do it. I wish to know the names and the structures of these wood sampels. I would also like to have my own wood library in the near future.

object-27.text: Alright! Great then. Let me give you a tour over the institute.

object-28.text: How do you identify these wood samples?

object-29.text: Okay, the identification is based on the structural features of wood.

object-30.text: Ow yes! If I remember correctly, structural features are wood features based on their cellular make-up which are visible to the naked eyes or needs the aid of hand lens.

object-31.text: Yes, exactly! These include: pores, parenchyma types, wood rays, ducts and included phloem.

object-32.text: Yes, it turned my memories of FPPS 11 back in 2016.

object-33.text: By the way, we are using this tablet to identify various structural features of wood.

object-35.text:
Let's discuss one by one the different structural features of wood. Let's start with:

1. PORES are cross-sections of vessel elements. These provide a number of features that are of value in identification like the size, shape, number and distrubution, occlusions, topography and type and arrangement.

		a. Size of pores can vary from minute to large.

		b. Shape of pores can be rounded, angular or oval.

		c. Number of pores can range from few to numerous.

object-36.text:
Okay let me test you about the sizes, shapes and frequency of pores.

		Select the letter that best describe the cross-section displayed on the left.

object-37.text: d. Occlusions. Pores may also be empty or filled. Two types of occlusions that can be found inside the pores are tyloses and deposits.

object-38.text:
Okay this time you should be able to differentiate a deposit from a tylosis.

		Select the letter that best describe the cross-section displayed on the left.

object-39.text: e. Topography refers to the classification of hardwoods on the basis of pore size and distribution. There are three types of topography:

object-40.text:
The lesson is becoming more and more complicated but I know you can do this.

		Select the letter that best describes the cross-section displayed on the left.

object-41.text:
f. Types and arragement

Pores are found in different arrangements which are useful for identification purposes, they may be grouped or arranged as follows:

object-42.text:
Now, let's test your familiarization about pore type and arrangement

		Select the letter that best describes the cross-section displayed on the left.

object-43.text: Wow! That's a lot but very interesting.

object-44.text: Yes, but that's only one essential feature for wood identification. Listen, I'll discuss other features further such as parenchyma, wood rays, ducts and included phloem.

object-46.text:
Secondly, another essential feature for wood identification is the PARENCHYMA.

These are short-thin-walled cells concerned primarily with storage and to a lesser extend in the distribution of carbohydrates. It remains functional for a longer period compared to other wood elements, lighter in color than the surrounding tissues and may appear in the form of dots, lines and bands.

object-47.text:
There are three major types of parenchyma in hardwoods:

		a. Apotracheal parenchyma - parenchyma cells arranged independent of vessels/pores. There are three types: concentric, diffuse and diffuse in aggregates parenchyma.

		b. Paratracheal parenchyma - parenchyma associated with pores. Examples that are common in Philippine species are vasicentric, aliform, aliform confluent and banded confluent.
		Scanty and unilaterally paratracheal parenchyma are uncommon in Philippine wood species.

		c. Boundary parenchyma - parenchyma cells found at the margins of a growth ring.

object-48.text:
Now, let's see if you can recall all those parenchyma types

		Select the letter that best describes the cross-section displayed on the left.

object-49.text:
Thirdly, the presence of WOOD RAYS is also helpful basis for identifying wood.

Wood rays are ribbon-shaped strand of tissue extending in a radial direction across the grain. Ray width is important in wood identification. Wood ray width can vary from:

		a. Narrow wood rays

		b. Broad wood rays

		c. Combination of narrow and moderately broad wood rays are also present in some wood species.

object-50.text:
You must be able to distinguish different variations in terms of width of wood rays

		Select the letter that best describes the cross-section displayed on the left.

object-51.text: We already reviewed three important features of wood namely: PORES, PARENCHYMA and WOOD RAYS.

object-52.text: Yes and I believe there are more structural features which can also be helpful for identification.

object-53.text: Yes, probably you are referring to the present of ducts and included phloem.

object-54.text:
Fourthly, the presence of ducts is very helpful as well.

Ducts are longitudinally and/or horizontally oriented openings that are surrounded by cells secreting resinous, oily or gummy substance. These may occur as a normal characteristic feature or may arise due to injury. It may be arranged in diffuse or concentric manner.

Ducts can be also filled or empty, meaning, resin, gum or oil can be very visible at the surface of the ducts or it can be occluded on its inner portion.

object-55.text:
Lastly, the presence of included phloem is very helpful too.

Included phloem refers to the presence of phloem (bark) in the xylem (wood).

object-56.text:
You must be able to distinguish different variations in terms of width of wood rays

		Select the letter that best describes the cross-section displayed on the left.

object-57.text: Those are the structural features essential for wood identification

object-text.text: GROSS FEATURES OF SELECTED PHILIPPINE WOOD SPECIES

object-dialogue.text: Hi Sue! Welcome to your first day at work.

options.l-db-b: Light to Dark Brown to Black
options.py-drb: Pale Yellow to Dark Reddish Brown
options.w-pp-lrb: White, Pale Pink to Light Reddish Brown
options.yr-cb: Yellowish Red to Chestnut Brown (w/ Black Streaks)

options.combination: Combination of moderately broad and narrow
